    • SIAMCAT: Statistical Inference of Associations between Microbial Communities And host phenoTypes

    SIAMCAT: Statistical Inference of Associations between Microbial Communities And host phenoTypes

    Konrad Zych, Jakob Wirbel, Nicolai Karcher, and Georg Zeller

    2018-01-02

    Introduction

    SIAMCAT Workflow

    library(SIAMCAT)
fn.in.feat <- system.file("extdata", "feat_crc_study-pop-I_N141_tax_profile_mocat_bn_specI_clusters.tsv", package = "SIAMCAT")
fn.in.label <- system.file("extdata", "label_crc_study-pop-I_N141_tax_profile_mocat_bn_specI_clusters.tsv", package = "SIAMCAT")
fn.in.meta <- system.file("extdata", "num_metadata_crc_study-pop-I_N141_tax_profile_mocat_bn_specI_clusters.tsv", package = "SIAMCAT")

    Read/Validate/Filter Data

    feat  <- read.features(fn.in.feat)
    ## The provided feature names were not semantically correct for use in R, they were updated.
    label <- read.labels(fn.in.label)
meta  <- read.meta(fn.in.meta)
    validated.files <- validate.data(feat = feat, 
                                 label = label, 
                                 meta = meta )
    results <- select.samples(meta=meta, 
                          feat=feat, 
                          label=label$label, 
                          filter='age', 
                          allowed.set=NULL, 
                          allowed.range=c(0,120))
    ## allowed.range  = [0,120]
## 
## Removed 0 samples with age not in [0, 120] (retaining 141)
    feat = results$feat
label$label = results$label
meta = results$meta
    feat.filtered <- filter.feat(feat = feat,  
                             filter.method = 'abundance', 
                             cutoff =0.001, 
                             recomp.prop = FALSE, 
                             rm.unmapped = TRUE)
    ## Removed 1546 features whose values did not exceed 0.001 in any sample (retaining 208)
## Removed 1 features corresponding to UNMAPPED reads (retaining 207)

    Association/Confounder Testing

    # confounder.check(meta=meta, label=label, fn.plot=paste0(output.dir, 'conf_check.pdf'))
    # check.associations(feat = feat.filtered,
#                    label = label, sort.by='fc',
#                    fn.plot = paste0(output.dir, '/assoc.pdf'), 
#                    alpha = 0.05, mult.corr = "fdr",
#                    detect.lim = 10^-6, max.show = 50, plot.type = "quantile.box",
#                    panels=c("fc", "prevalence", "auroc"))

    Data Normalization

    normalized.data <- normalize.feat(feat = feat.filtered, 
                                  norm.method = "log.unit", 
                                  norm.param=list(log.n0 = 1e-06, n.p=2, norm.margin=1))
    ## Performing de novo normalization using the  log.unit  method
## Feature sparsity before normalization: 45.11598%
## Feature sparsity after normalization: 0%
    feat.norm = normalized.data$feat.norm

    Model building and Prediction

    pred.names = strsplit(c('fobt'), ',', fixed=TRUE)[[1]]
feat.fobt = add.meta.pred(feat = feat.norm, 
                          meta = meta, 
                          pred.names = pred.names, 
                          std.meta = TRUE)
    ## adding fobt
## filling in 1 missing values by mean imputation
## standardize metadata feature fobt 
## added 1 meta-variables as predictors to the feature matrix
    data.split <- data.splitter(label = label, 
                            num.folds = 5, 
                            num.resample = 2, 
                            stratify = TRUE, 
                            inseparable = NULL, 
                            meta = NULL)
    ## [1] 5
## 
## +++ Splitting the dataset:
##    + Fold 1 contains 29 examples
##    + Fold 2 contains 29 examples
##    + Fold 3 contains 29 examples
##    + Fold 4 contains 27 examples
##    + Fold 5 contains 27 examples
## [1] 5
## 
## +++ Splitting the dataset:
##    + Fold 1 contains 29 examples
##    + Fold 2 contains 29 examples
##    + Fold 3 contains 29 examples
##    + Fold 4 contains 27 examples
##    + Fold 5 contains 27 examples
    plm.out <- train.model(feat=feat.fobt, 
                       label=label,  
                       method = "lasso",
                       data.split=data.split, 
                       stratify = TRUE,
                       modsel.crit=list("pr"),  
                       min.nonzero.coeff = 5)
    ## cv_fold1_rep1 contains 112 training examples
## cv_fold1_rep2 contains 112 training examples
## cv_fold2_rep1 contains 112 training examples
## cv_fold2_rep2 contains 112 training examples
## cv_fold3_rep1 contains 112 training examples
## cv_fold3_rep2 contains 112 training examples
## cv_fold4_rep1 contains 114 training examples
## cv_fold4_rep2 contains 114 training examples
## cv_fold5_rep1 contains 114 training examples
## cv_fold5_rep2 contains 114 training examples
## 
## Preparing to train lasso models on 10 training set samples...
## 
## Training on cv_fold1_rep1 (1 of 10)
## 
## Training on cv_fold1_rep2 (2 of 10)
## 
## Training on cv_fold2_rep1 (3 of 10)
## 
## Training on cv_fold2_rep2 (4 of 10)
## 
## Training on cv_fold3_rep1 (5 of 10)
## 
## Training on cv_fold3_rep2 (6 of 10)
## 
## Training on cv_fold4_rep1 (7 of 10)
## 
## Training on cv_fold4_rep2 (8 of 10)
## 
## Training on cv_fold5_rep1 (9 of 10)
## 
## Training on cv_fold5_rep2 (10 of 10)
    ## Warning in vec[2] <- beta: number of items to replace is not a multiple of
## replacement length
    ## Warning in vec[3:length(vec)] <- as.numeric(beta): number of items to
## replace is not a multiple of replacement length
    ## Warning in vec[2] <- beta: number of items to replace is not a multiple of
## replacement length
    ## Warning in vec[3:length(vec)] <- as.numeric(beta): number of items to
## replace is not a multiple of replacement length
    ## Warning in vec[2] <- beta: number of items to replace is not a multiple of
## replacement length
    ## Warning in vec[3:length(vec)] <- as.numeric(beta): number of items to
## replace is not a multiple of replacement length
    ## Warning in vec[2] <- beta: number of items to replace is not a multiple of
## replacement length
    ## Warning in vec[3:length(vec)] <- as.numeric(beta): number of items to
## replace is not a multiple of replacement length
    ## Warning in vec[2] <- beta: number of items to replace is not a multiple of
## replacement length
    ## Warning in vec[3:length(vec)] <- as.numeric(beta): number of items to
## replace is not a multiple of replacement length
    ## Warning in vec[2] <- beta: number of items to replace is not a multiple of
## replacement length
    ## Warning in vec[3:length(vec)] <- as.numeric(beta): number of items to
## replace is not a multiple of replacement length
    ## Warning in vec[2] <- beta: number of items to replace is not a multiple of
## replacement length
    ## Warning in vec[3:length(vec)] <- as.numeric(beta): number of items to
## replace is not a multiple of replacement length
    ## Warning in vec[2] <- beta: number of items to replace is not a multiple of
## replacement length
    ## Warning in vec[3:length(vec)] <- as.numeric(beta): number of items to
## replace is not a multiple of replacement length
    ## Warning in vec[2] <- beta: number of items to replace is not a multiple of
## replacement length
    ## Warning in vec[3:length(vec)] <- as.numeric(beta): number of items to
## replace is not a multiple of replacement length
    ## Warning in vec[2] <- beta: number of items to replace is not a multiple of
## replacement length
    ## Warning in vec[3:length(vec)] <- as.numeric(beta): number of items to
## replace is not a multiple of replacement length
    prediction = make.predictions(feat=feat.fobt, 
                              label=label, 
                              data.split=data.split,
                              models.list=plm.out)
    ## cv_fold1_rep1 contains 112 training examples
## cv_fold1_rep2 contains 112 training examples
## cv_fold2_rep1 contains 112 training examples
## cv_fold2_rep2 contains 112 training examples
## cv_fold3_rep1 contains 112 training examples
## cv_fold3_rep2 contains 112 training examples
## cv_fold4_rep1 contains 114 training examples
## cv_fold4_rep2 contains 114 training examples
## cv_fold5_rep1 contains 114 training examples
## cv_fold5_rep2 contains 114 training examples
## Applying  on cv_fold1_rep1 (1 of 10)...
## Applying  on cv_fold1_rep2 (2 of 10)...
## Applying  on cv_fold2_rep1 (3 of 10)...
## Applying  on cv_fold2_rep2 (4 of 10)...
## Applying  on cv_fold3_rep1 (5 of 10)...
## Applying  on cv_fold3_rep2 (6 of 10)...
## Applying  on cv_fold4_rep1 (7 of 10)...
## Applying  on cv_fold4_rep2 (8 of 10)...
## Applying  on cv_fold5_rep1 (9 of 10)...
## Applying  on cv_fold5_rep2 (10 of 10)...

## Combined test AUC = 1 (m=1, s.d.=0)

## Min: 0.9483925, Median: 0.9741962, Mean: 0.9741962

    Model Evaluation and Interpretation

    eval.data <-  eval.predictions(label = label, pred = prediction$mat)
    ## Warning in ci.se.roc(roc, ...): ci.se() of a ROC curve with AUC == 1 is
## always a null interval and can be misleading.
